grounding: Identification strategies concern what can be learned about the value of a parameter based on the data and the model assumptions. The literature on partial identification is motivated by the fact that it is not possible to learn the exact value of the parameter for many empirically relevant cases. A typical result in the literature on partial identification is a statement about characterizing the identified set, which summarizes what can be learned about the parameter of interest given the data and model assumptions. For instance, this may mean that the value of the parameter can be learned to be necessarily within some set of values. First, the review surveys the general frameworks that have been developed for conducting a partial identification analysis. Second, the review surveys some of the more recent results on partial identification.
generated_text: This paper reviews recent advancements in the field of partial identification, focusing on methodologies that leverage set identification, bounds, treatment effects, shape restrictions, and optimizing behavior. Partial identification approaches have gained prominence for their ability to provide robust inferences in the presence of model uncertainty and data limitations. We explore how these techniques have been applied to estimate treatment effects, offering a framework that accommodates a wide range of assumptions and data structures. The discussion highlights the role of shape restrictions and optimizing behavior in tightening the bounds of identified sets, thereby enhancing the precision of causal inferences. Through a synthesis of recent literature, this review underscores the potential of partial identification methods to address complex empirical questions, offering insights into their application across various domains of economic and social research.
